author: Claire MOYSE-FAURIE & Marie-Adèle NECHERÖ-JOREDIE
notes: The data used here are coming from a dictionnary made by Claire MOYSE-FAURIE & Marie-Adèle NECHERÖ-JOREDIE in 1989. It is presented in the book Dictionnaire Xârâcùù-Français (Nouvelle-Calédonie), Nouméa : Les Editions Populaires, 288 pp.It provides a phonological, greographical, and sociolinguistical introduction to the Xârâcùù, language spoken in the Kouaoua-Canala-Thio areas (located on the east cost of the New Caledonia Main Land ('Grande-Terre'). This book, intended to speakers usage, provides two lexicons, one in xârâcùù-french, and one in french-xârâcùù. Methodology used here to enter the lexical data : - The synonymy has been reduced by going through both lexicons.- When two words in Xârâcùù are presented with a slash (for instance \xãⁿdɨ/xãⁿdɤ\"
problems: it means that those words are two morphological forms of the same word (generally related to geographical distribution of this word).

id: - When both simple words and compound words are possible in Xârâcùù to translate a word in the list
language: we have opted for the simple words.

id: - When a word is not phonologically autonomous (i.e being a prefix or a suffix)
language: a dash has been put after the word (prefix) or before the word (suffix).

id: - When a word in the list can not be translated by a single general item in xârâcùù
language: some semantic specifications for each one of them have been provided in the 'author annotation' column."
silcode: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Central-Eastern Oceanic, Remote Oceanic, New Caledonian, Southern, South, Xaracuu-Xaragure

author: dust
glottocode: Refers to the dust like 'ashes' or 'coming from wood' and 'falling down'

author: dust
glottocode: Refers to the dust 'in the air'

author: to spit
glottocode: 'to spit, to reject something like food'

author: to kill
glottocode: 'to do something that has death as a consequence'

author: to swell
glottocode: In two words, means 'to inflate something by blowing on it', there is no ather term to refere as 'to swell'

author: big
glottocode: Can be used as a verb with a similar meaning

author: big
glottocode: Used for people and things that are big, or for quantities that are big

author: short
glottocode: Used as a general term for short without any distinction between height and length features of objects

author: narrow
glottocode: The distinction between those three words seems to be related to syntactic purposes

author: wide
glottocode: The distinction between those two words seems to be related to syntactic purposes as well

author: new
glottocode: Something new that comes from the outside word not endemic ('a stranger' for instance)

author: new
glottocode: (1) Something new, mostly vegetables, like a new tree, a young coconut, etc

author: new
glottocode: Tends to mean 'for the first time'

author: at
glottocode: Used for instance in sentences like 'he is angry at his wife'

author: at
glottocode: Prepositions used for event without motion (for instance 'he is at the beach')

author: at
glottocode: Prepositions used for event without motion (for instance 'he is at the beach')

author: who?
glottocode: Used for more respectful way of adressing

author: other
glottocode: Appears to be used for anaphoric purposes

author: other
glottocode: Used before a noun (i.e is the more general word for 'other')

author: no, not
glottocode: Provides a negative polarity to a sentence
